A geometric construction of Mathon's perp-system from four
lines of PG(5, 3)
John Bamberg and Frank De Clerck
Abstract. We give a new construction of the Mathon perp-system of the five dimensional
projective space over the field with three elements, starting from four lines.

1. Introduction
There are certain maximal arcs of PG(2, q 2 ), q even, constructed by Denniston [4] for which
there is a non-degenerate orthogonal polarity of PG(2, q 2 ) such that for every point of the
maximal arc, its polar line is an exterior line of the arc. Such maximal arcs are called self-polar
and they give rise to interesting partial geometries with parameters pg(q 2 −1, (q 2 +1)(q−1), q−1)
(see [2]). If we choose a basis for GF(q 2 ) over GF(q), we can identify the vectors of GF(q 2 )3
with the vectors of GF(q)6 . Thus a maximal arc of PG(2, q 2 ) corresponds to an SPG-regulus of
lines of PG(5, q), however, the resulting polarity is degenerate1. The notion of a perp-system was
introduced by [3] as a particular type of self-polar SPG-regulus of a finite projective space, and
moreover, one that produces a partial geometry under linear representation. A perp-system P
of a projective space PG(d, q), with respect to a polarity ρ, is a maximal set of mutually disjoint
r-subspaces of PG(d, q) such that every two not necessarily distinct elements of P are opposite
(with respect to ρ). So in particular, every element of a perp-system is non-singular with respect
to ρ. By maximal we mean that the cardinality of P attains the theoretical upper bound of

(see [3, Theorem 2.1]). In [3], a particular perp-system M attributed to Mathon was given as
a set of 21 lines of PG(5, 3) with respect to a symplectic polarity. It turns out that M is also
a perp-system with respect to some elliptic and some hyperbolic polarity, and its full stabiliser
in PGL(6, 3) is S5 ; a maximal subgroup of PGSp(6, 3). Mathon's perp-system is the only known
perp-system not arising from a maximal arc of PG(2, q).
In trying to understand the only known perp-system not arising from a maximal arc, the
authors found that everything begins with finding as set F4 of four curious lines of the projective
space PG(5, 3). Every line of PG(5, 3) can be represented by a 2 × 6 matrix of rank 2, and so we
can write these four lines so that they look like a frame of a projective plane (i.e., the blow-up
of a frame of PG(2, 9)):

In this note we give a geometric construction of Mathon's perp-system, starting from the
set of lines F4 above. Via this construction, we also show that Mathon's perp-system is related
to the generalised quadrangle W(2). We should also note that Mathon's perp-system provides
insight into the embedding of A5 as a maximal subgroup of PSp(6, 3). As far as the authors
are aware, the only raison d'être for this embedding comes from the character table of SL(2, 5).
The faithful absolutely irreducible ordinary character of SL(2, 5) of degree 6 has zero 3-defect
and is rational, hence it is absolutely irreducible over GF(3). The Frobenius-Schur indicator of
this character is −1, hence both the ordinary representation and its representation over GF(3)
admit a symplectic form, which we can see from the Brauer character table below (in mod 3):

2. A Construction of Mathon's Perp-System
A partial geometry pg(s, t, α) is a partial linear space such that every line contains s + 1
points, every point is incident with t + 1 lines and for a point P and line l which are not
incident, there are α points on l collinear with P . We have already spoken fleetingly of partial
geometries in the introduction where we mentioned that maximal arcs and perp-systems give
rise to partial geometries. In turn, a partial geometry gives rise to a strongly regular graph
srg((s + 1)(st + α)/α, s(t + 1), s − 1 + t(α − 1), α(t + 1)),
and up to duality, we only know of about eight constructions of partial geometries (see [2, 4.1]).
For α = 2, the only known partial geometries are sporadic: the Van Lint-Schrijver, Haemers
and Mathon partial geometries, the latter arising from Mathon's perp-system M.
From [3], it is known that M consists of 21 lines of PG(5, 3) forming a partial line-spread.
The complement of M contains precisely 21 solids mutually intersecting in lines, and there
are exactly three solids through any point in this complement. They showed by an exhaustive
computer search, that up to projectivity, there was only one such configuration of solids. This
was enough for Cristina Tonesi [9] to ascertain that if a partial geometry with α = 2 is a linear
representation of a perp-system, then it is equivalent to the partial geometry arising from the
Mathon perp-system. We will now develop a construction of Mathon's perp-system from the
four lines F4 . Let X be the following skew-symmetric matrix over GF(3):

2.2. From Five to Six. Most of us are familiar with the isomorphism of S5 with PGL(2, 5)
which gives rise to two 5-transitive actions of S5 : on five and six points respectively. To obtain
the action on six points directly from the action on five points, one simply notices that S5
has six subgroups of order 5 which are permuted naturally under the conjugation action of S5 ;
thus producing the multiply transitive action on 6 elements. Likewise, the stabiliser S5 of F5
determines a special set of six lines from L. The total number of lines of PG(6, 3) is 11011, which
you will notice is congruent to 1 modulo 5. Hence a 5-cycle has a unique fixed line. The six
lines F6 we want are precisely those lines of PG(5, 3) which are fixed by some 5-cycle in S5 .

its action on five points, we simply consider the action of S5 on its 5-cycles. To invert this
procedure, we take blocks of imprimitivity consisting of triples on the 15 pairs of elements from

3. The generalised quadrangle W(2)
The smallest thick generalised quadrangle is W(2) and it has 15 points and 15 lines. The most
common construction of this generalised quadrangle is to take a symplectic form on V := GF(2)4 ,
for example hx, yi = x1 y4 + x4 y1 + x2 y3 + x3 y2 , and then consider the two-dimensional subspaces
of V for which this form vanishes. These two-spaces together with all of the nonzero vectors of V
form the unique generalised quadrangle of order 2 (up to isomorphism). The oldest construction
of W(2) is due to Sylvester (see [7, Section 6]). Consider the six element set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. A
duad is an unordered pair of distinct elements from this set and a syntheme is a set of three
duads which are mutually disjoint. One obtains a generalised quadrangle of order 2 by letting
the duads be the points, synthemes as the lines and natural inclusion for incidence. It can be
easily shown that Sylvester's duad-syntheme geometry is a generalised quadrangle of order 2.

Remark 3.3.
(i) Using the Sylvester's model of W(2), one can also construct (see [7, Section 6]) the
unique generalised quadrangle on 27 points and 45 lines.
(ii) An affine embedding of W(2) into AG(3, 3) is known [8]. We have not been able to
establish a connection between this construction and ours, although they have the
underlying field in common.
